body:
Getting it to work with WebDAV would probably be the easiest thing to do.

Can you get free accounts?  Or could you lend me the credentials for yours for a bit?

Here's a sub account to play with

```
[stack]
type = webdav
url = https://tafelpoowt.stackstorage.com/remote.php/webdav
vendor = owncloud
user = rclone
pass = rclone123
```

The webdav token doesn't work.
Token:  qA0ekrjw281EJKPPLQHLUf4oaX8

I'm able to list, copy, sync. The second sync doesn't skip any files though.
See https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/580#issuecomment-336873620
```
stefaan@host:~/isos$ rclone sync somedir stack:somedir --progress
Transferred:       18.999M / 18.999 MBytes, 100%, 1.440 MBytes/s, ETA 0s
Errors:                 0
Checks:                28 / 28, 100%
Transferred:           19 / 19, 100%
Elapsed time:       13.1s
stefaan@host:~/isos$ rclone sync somedir stack:somedir --progress
Transferred:       18.999M / 18.999 MBytes, 100%, 1.799 MBytes/s, ETA 0s
Errors:                 0
Checks:                19 / 19, 100%
Transferred:           19 / 19, 100%
Elapsed time:       10.5s

```

I see why it is trying to upload everything twice...

You have the "owncloud" type configured, and rclone is trying to upload the files with timestamps

```
2019/04/25 16:51:06 DEBUG : PUT /remote.php/webdav/jikumel HTTP/1.1
Host: tafelpoowt.stackstorage.com
User-Agent: rclone/v1.47.0-022-ge275ad80-beta
Content-Length: 73
Authorization: XXXX
Content-Type: application/octet-stream
Oc-Checksum: SHA1:cf3b1d3c67da30ed95a50e4dcb69dbf16262a7d9
X-Oc-Mtime: 1556207416.529042
Accept-Encoding: gzip
```

However the timestamps of the files are not being updated, they are being set to the time of upload.

I don't know why the server doesn't support `X-Oc-Mtime` that might be something to ask the provider. It doesn't seem to support `Oc-Checksum` either.

If you set `vendor = other` then the sync will work properly, but losing the modification times and the sha1sums is not ideal, so might be worth a ticket to the vendor. They might be filtering them out in their frontent proxies or something like that.

> The webdav token doesn't work.
> Token: qA0ekrjw281EJKPPLQHLUf4oaX8

How have you been attempting to use that?

In the [Settings](https://tafelpoowt.stackstorage.com/settings) tab you can create access tokens for webdav.
One would assume this could replace the user / password config... but it doesn't.
I've tested both with and without the user field, but it always shows access denied.

I contacted support and they said the access tokens are related to 2FA.
When 2FA is not enabled, you need to stick to password authentication.

They will look into the issue with the headers.

> I contacted support and they said the access tokens are related to 2FA.
> When 2FA is not enabled, you need to stick to password authentication.
> 
> They will look into the issue with the headers.

Great - let me know what happens.

> I contacted support and they said the access tokens are related to 2FA.
> When 2FA is not enabled, you need to stick to password authentication.
> 
> They will look into the issue with the headers.

Any update?ðŸ˜Š

In what format does RClone send the `X-Oc-Mtime` header? STACK only supports an integer with a unix timestamp currently. It seems you are sending a number with microseconds which cannot be parsed and is silently ignored.

Here is an rclone with X-OC-Mtime as an integer - can you give it a test?

https://beta.rclone.org/branch/v1.51.0-009-g629a88d5-fix-3126-webdav-time-beta/ (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

I can't find the specification for X-OC-Mtime - can anyone point me at them?

Certainly owncloud and nextcloud only keep timestamps to the nearest second so I'm not sure why I ever thought it needed fractional seconds.

I've tested the new version but I saw still that the Mtime header is in an incorrect format.  The fractional seconds are not included anymore but they are replaced with zero's. So the application discards the header in silence.  For example the header that this version of rclone sends is this: `X-Oc-Mtime: 1331392380.000000`

I have not found a formal specification about the header on either the Nextcloud or Owncloud documentation. But the is an direction on the following page:  [https://docs.nextcloud.com/server/18/developer_manual/client_apis/WebDAV/chunking.html?highlight=mtime](url)

So in my understanding the X-OC-Mtime is just an simple representation of an Unix timestamp returned with the default PHP functions (getMtime()) and formatted without any changes in Next or owncloud.

@leander091 I made a mistake with that one try this!


https://beta.rclone.org/branch/v1.51.0-009-gdfc31ab7-fix-3126-webdav-time-beta/ (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

> I have not found a format specification about the header on either the Nextcloud or Owncloud documentation. But the is an direction on the following page: [https://docs.nextcloud.com/server/18/developer_manual/client_apis/WebDAV/chunking.html?highlight=mtime](url)
> 
> So in my understanding the X-OC-Mtime is just an simple representation of an Unix timestamp returned with the default PHP functions (getMtime()) and formatted without any changes in Next or owncloud.

That certainly looks suggestive that it is an integer...

nextcloud and owncloud are ignoring the extra precision too.
@ncw  I have tested the new beta and it works like a charm.  It checks the modification time as expected and does not upload a file if the time is equal to the version on the server.
